description:
Phytophthora ramorum is a plant pathogenic oomycete that is the causal agent of sudden oak death (SOD) and other plant diseases. It is an invasive species that was first identified in the mid-1990s in California and Oregon, and has since spread to other regions.

Phytophthora ramorum is a water mold, a type of eukaryotic microorganism that shares some characteristics with fungi but is more closely related to algae. It produces motile zoospores that can swim in water and infect a wide range of plant hosts, including oak trees, rhododendrons, and other woody and herbaceous plants.

The pathogen can cause significant damage and mortality in affected plant populations, leading to widespread ecological and economic impacts. It is considered a serious threat to forestry and nursery industries, as well as natural ecosystems where it has been introduced.

Research on Phytophthora ramorum continues to focus on understanding its biology, epidemiology, and management strategies to prevent and control the spread of this destructive plant pathogen.
